facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 89-93 of 1964 are appeals by special leave from the judgment and orders dated August 30, 1961 and June 13, 1961 in Special Civil Application Nos. 440, 441, 509, 510 and 7 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 89--93 of 1964. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and orders dated August 30, 1961 and June 13, 1961 in Special Civil Application Nos. 440, 441,509, 510 and 7 of 1961.

facts.text: The five appeals raise a common question of interpretation of r. 19 of the Displaced Persons Compensation Rehabilitation Rules, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: These five appeals by special leave raise a companymon question of interpretation of r. 19 of the Displaced Persons  Compensation Rehabilitation  Rules, 1955  hereinafter referred to as the Rules . It is companymon ground that numberhing turns on any dissimilarity in the facts of each appeal.

facts.text: Respondent Lachman Hotchand Kriplani is a displaced person from West Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: It will accordingly suffice if facts in Civil Appeal No. 93 of 1964 are set out. The respondent, Lachman Hotchand Kriplani, is a displaced person from West Pakistan.

facts.text: Lachman Hotchand Kriplani and his three brothers owned 731 acres of agricultural land in District Nawabshah, Taluka Nawab Shah, Sind, now in Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: He has three brothers. They owned 731 acres of agricultural land in District Nawabshah, Taluka Nawab Shah, Sind--now in Pakistan.

facts.text: Respondent submitted a claim under the Displaced Persons Claims Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent submitted a claim under the Displaced Persons  Claims  Act, 1950  XLIV of 1950 --hereinafter referred to as the Claims Act.

facts.text: Respondent's claim was that he owned 1/4 share of 731 acres and 14 ghuntas standing in the name of Fatehchand.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents claim was that he owned 1/4 share of 731 acres and 14 ghuntas standing in the name, of Fatehehand.

facts.text: Claim Officer accepted the claim by order dated October 7, 1952 and assessed it as 94-3 standard acres.

anchor.surface_text: The Claim Officer, by order dated October 7, 1952, accepted the claim and assessed his claim as 94-3 standard acres.

facts.text: On July 2, 1955, respondent applied for compensation under the Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Act, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On July 2, 1955, the respondent applied for companypensation under the Displaced Persons  Compensation and Rehabilitation  Act  XLIV Of 1954 --hereinafter referred to as the Compensation Act.

facts.text: In compensation application, respondent stated he was not a member of a Joint Hindu Family in Pakistan, but a co-sharer along with three others who filed separate claims.

anchor.surface_text: In the application he stated that he was number a member of a Joint Hindu Family in Pakistan, but his claim was as a companysharer alongwith three others, who had filed separate claims.

facts.text: Assistant Settlement Commissioner held enquiry and by order dated March 3, 1960, held that the four alleged co-sharers were members of a Joint Hindu Family, and the whole agricultural land claim was to be treated as joint property.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Settlement Commissioner was, however, number satisfied with this assertion and after holding an enquiry, by order dated March 3, 1960, he held that the four alleged companysharers were members of a Joint Hindu Family, and the whole agricultural land claim was to be treated as joint property.

facts.text: On August 29, 1960, a statement of account was issued to the respondent showing his claim assessed as Rs. 10,701/- gross compensation.

anchor.surface_text: On August 29, 1960, a statement of account was issued to the respondent. This statement showed that his claim was assessed as Rs. 10,701/- gross companypensation.

facts.text: The compensation was calculated as 1/4th share of 376 standard acres and 12 units, converting to Rs. 10,701/- per Rules 51 and 56.

anchor.surface_text: This figure was arrived at, as stated in the affidavit of the Assistant Settlement Commissioner, thus The claim was assessed for 376 standard acres and 12 units out of which the petitioner had 1/4th share. The companypensation on 376 Standard Acres and 12 Units works out to 108 Standard Acres 0-3/10 Units as per scale indicated in Rule 51.

facts.text: On October 28, 1960, respondent served notice on Regional Settlement Commissioner to rectify the statement of account, claiming r.20 or r.19 applies.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then on October 28, 1960, served a numberice on the Regional Settlement Commissioner calling upon him to rectify the statement of account, failing which he will be companystrained to move the High Court under arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Assistant Settlement Commissioner replied that calculation was correct.

anchor.surface_text: In reply, the Assistant Settlement Commissioner informed him that the calculation had been done companyrectly.

facts.text: Respondent filed petition under Articles 226 and 227 in Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, he filed a petition under arts. 226 and 227, in the Bombay High Court.

facts.text: Bombay High Court allowed the petition, set aside the statement of account dated August 29, 1960, and directed application of r.19, 51, 56 etc.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court allowed the petition and set aside the statement of account furnished to the petitioner on August 29, 1960, and directed that the respondent shall give the benefit of r. 19 and determine the amount of companypensation payable to him in accordance with the provisions of rr. 19, 51 and 56 and other rules of the Displaced Persons  Compensation and Rehabilitation  Rules, 1955.

facts.text: Appellant obtained special leave, appeals before Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant having obtained special leave, the appeals are number before us.

facts.text: In High Court, respondent's counsel did not challenge the finding that respondent and brothers were members of joint family.

anchor.surface_text: We may mention at the outset that in the High Court the respondents companynsel did number challenge the finding of the Assistant Settlement Commissioner that the respondent and his brothers were members of a joint family.

facts.text: Respondent's claim verified by order dated October 7, 1952 is a verified claim.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that the claim of the respondent verified by order dated October 7, 1952, is a verified claim.

facts.text: Agricultural land in Sind was notified under Displaced Persons Claims Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that agricultural land in Sind was so numberified.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that r.19 applies to agricultural land claims of joint families.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, in agreement with the High Court, we hold that r. 19 will apply to the claim of the respondent in respect of agricultural land left by him as a member of the Joint Hindu Family.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed with costs, and other appeals also dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts. As stated in the beginning, it is companymon ground that if this appeal fails the other appeals must also fail. They are accordingly dismissed with companyts.

issues.text: Does rule 19 of the Displaced Persons (Compensation and Rehabilitation) Rules, 1955 apply to verified claims relating to agricultural land left by members of an undivided Hindu family in West Pakistan?

anchor.surface_text: These five appeals by special leave raise a companymon question of interpretation of r. 19 of the Displaced Persons Compensation Rehabilitation Rules, 1955 hereinafter referred to as the Rules .

issues.text: Do sections 4, 5, 6, 7 and 8 of the Compensation Act distinguish between urban land and agricultural land as long as the agricultural land is the subject-matter of a verified claim?

anchor.surface_text: Before we deal with the 1955 Rules, it is apparent that ss. 4, 5, 6, 7 and 8 do number in any manner distinguish between urban land and agricultural land as long as the agricultural land is the subject-matter of a verified claim.

issues.text: Does Chapter IV of the Rules, in which r. 19 occurs, deal with verified claims for agricultural lands?

anchor.surface_text: What emerges from a companysideration of these rules in Chapter IV is that we must companysider each rule and see whether it has application to a claim for companypensation in respect of agricultural land.

issues.text: Does rule 20 apply to a claim relating to agricultural land left in West Pakistan which is owned by more than one claimant as co-owners?

anchor.surface_text: r. 20 recognises the general rule and provides that where a claim relates to property left in West Pakistan, which is owned by more than one claimant as co-owners, the unit for the assessment of compensation shall be the share of each co-owner...

issues.text: Does rule 19 apply to the respondent's case or alternatively rule 20?

anchor.surface_text: The heading Special Provision for payment of compensation to joint families is general. So is sub-rule (1). The word properties is general and would include agricultural land. That this is the meaning is also borne out if we consider the word claim.

holdings.text: r. 19 will apply to the claim of the respondent in respect of agricultural land left by him as a member of the Joint Hindu Family.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, in agreement with the High Court, we hold that r. 19 will apply to the claim of the respondent in respect of agricultural land left by him as a member of the Joint Hindu Family.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language of r.19(1) is general and includes agricultural properties; verified claim includes agricultural land; ss.4-8 of Compensation Act make no distinction; Chapter IV rules including 12-15 apply to agricultural verified claims; Chapter VIII does not override rr.19-20; High Court conclusion correct.

holdings.text: ss. 4, 5, 6, 7 and 8 do not in any manner distinguish between urban land and agricultural land as long as the agricultural land is the subject-matter of a verified claim.

anchor.surface_text: Before we deal with the 1955 Rules, it is apparent that ss. 4, 5, 6, 7 and 8 do not in any manner distinguish between urban land and agricultural land as long as the agricultural land is the subject-matter of a verified claim.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of sections applies generally to verified claims; verified claims include agricultural land under Claims Act; public dues deduction applies widely including agricultural claims.

holdings.text: Chapter IV, in which r. 19 occurs, does deal with verified claims for agricultural lands.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we must reject the contention that Chapter IV, in which r. 19 occurs, does not deal with agricultural lands at all.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules 12,13,14 apply to agricultural verified claims as ss.5 and r.11 do; Appendix VII has columns for agricultural land and remarks on r.19 application.

holdings.text: rr. 12, 13 and 14 do apply to applications for compensation in respect of agricultural lands which are the subject-matter of a verified claim.

anchor.surface_text: Pausing here, it is difficult to hold that rr. 12, 13 and 14 do not apply to applications for compensation in respect of agricultural lands which are the subject-matter of a verified claim.

holdings.reasoning_summary: ss.5 and r.11 apply to agricultural verified claims; r.12 consolidates papers for such claims; Appendix VII supports.

holdings.text: r. 20 does apply to a claim in respect of agricultural land owned by more than one claimant as co-owners.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Attorney-General, when asked, said that even r. 20 would not apply to a claim in respect of agricultural land, but we are unable to accede to this contention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: r.20 recognizes general rule for co-owners; would be inequitable otherwise; language general including agricultural property; supports r.19 application.

holdings.text: There is nothing in Chapter VIII which modifies or overrides rr. 19 and 20.

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing in Chapter VIII which modifies or overrides rr. 19 and 20.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Chapter VIII deals with compensation modes for units determined under rr.19-20 (individuals, joint families, co-owners); no provision for joint families or co-owners therein.

holdings.text: The word properties [in r.19] is general and would include agricultural land.

anchor.surface_text: The heading Special Provision for payment of compensation to joint families is general. So is sub-rule (1). The word properties is general and would include agricultural land.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Heading and sub-r.1 general; claim refers to verified claims under s.4 including agricultural; no construction principle limits scope.

holdings.text: The finding of the Assistant Settlement Commissioner that the respondent and his brothers were members of a joint family [is accepted].

anchor.surface_text: We may mention at the outset that in the High Court the respondents counsel did not challenge the finding of the Assistant Settlement Commissioner that the respondent and his brothers were members of a joint family.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not challenged by respondent's counsel in High Court.
